trial_identification.studytitle: Investigating predictors of excess weight gain during pregnancy
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Investigating predictors of excess weight gain during pregnancy:a prospective observational cohort study.

interventions.interventions: Observational cohort study of weight gain in pregnancy from 12-15 weeks of pregnancy to 6 months post-partum.

primaryOutcome.outcome: To investigate the relationship between gestational weight gain and Intuitive Eating Scale scores
primaryOutcome.timepoint: weight gain to 37 weeks (term) pregnancy The Intuitive eating scale will be assessed at four time pionts during pregnancy (11-14, 18-21, 26-28 and 37 weeks and 6 months post-partum)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To investigate the relationship between gestational weight gain and sleep using the o Pittsburgh sleep score
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Weight gain to 37 weeks (term) pregnancy Pittsburgh sleep score will be performed at 12-14 w/ 18-21w, 25-29 w, 35-37 w

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To investigate the test retest reliability of the Intuitive eating Scale (IES) in pregnancy
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Comparison between Intuitive eating scores at 11-14 weeks and 18 -21 weeks of pregnancy

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To investigate the relationship between weight gain from 12 weeks of pregnancy till 6 months post- partum with sleep using the Pittsburgh sleep score
To investigate the relationship between gestational weight gain and mood using the Edinburgh depression score
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: 37 weeks pregnant Edinburgh depression score will be performed at 12-14 w/ 18-21w, 25-29 w, 35-37 w

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To investigate the relationship between gestational weight gain and activity at 12-14 w/ 18-21w, 25-29 w, 35-37 w using the Pregnancy Physical Activity Questionnaire
To investigate the relationship between gestational weight gain and anthropomorphic measurements (Height and weight measurement ,Waist measurement and Upper arm measurement) early in pregnancy
To investigate the relationship between weight gain from 12 weeks of pregnancy till 6 months post- partum with Intuitive Eating Scale scores
To investigate the relationship between weight gain from 12 weeks of pregnancy till 6 months post- partum with mood using the Edinburgh depression score
To investigate the relationship between weight gain from 12 weeks of pregnancy till 6 months post- partum with activity using the Pregnancy Physical Activity Questionnaire

To investigate the relationship between weight gain from 12 weeks of pregnancy till 6 months post- partum with anthropomorphic measurements (Height and weight measurement ,Waist measurement and Upper arm measurement) early in pregnancy

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Pregnant with an on-going wanted singleton pregnancy at the time of a Nuchal translucency ultrasound (11-14weeks) English speaking / reading skills Consents to take part Aged 18-45
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Home address outside of metropolitan Dunedin

trial_design.statisticalmethods: Regression modeling for hypothesis generation about the relationship between gestational weight gain and sleep, mood and activity; anthropomorphic measurements early in pregnancy

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Excess weight gain during pregnancy is associated with negative outcomes for mother and child. Interventions to reduce excess gestational weight gain can be costly and have not been effective to date. Our aim is to establish a simple way of identifying those women who are likely to gain excess weight during pregnancy in order to enable midwives and obstetricians to direct interventions towards women most at risk. Helping those women at risk of excess weight gain during pregnancy should make interventions work better and thus be cost-effective.
ethicsAndSummary.publicnotes: Please email pregnancy.weight@otago.ac.nz for further information
